headline: Saks Is Struggling to Stay Afloat. The Dealmaker Behind the Scenes Did Just Fine.
summary: It has long been a truism that retailing increasingly will become digital and that for a physical store to survive it must be special (or “experiential”) and probably have a digital presence.  To wit, the Saks Fifth Avenue imbroglio, a complex stew of myriad brands and deals that was driven by one such individual.  To get you up to speed—this is one of those “fast moving” situations—Saks Global Enterprises, the holding company that operates Saks (as well as Bergdorf Goodman and Neiman Marcus), is strapped for cash, having skipped a $100 million payment to bondholders on Dec. 30 (Happy New Year to you!).

content.title: Saks Is Struggling to Stay Afloat. The Dealmaker Behind the Scenes Did Just Fine.
content.summary: It has long been a truism that retailing increasingly will become digital and that for a physical store to survive it must be special (or “experiential”) and probably have a digital presence. To get you up to speed—this is one of those “fast moving” situations—Saks Global Enterprises, the holding company that operates Saks (as well as Bergdorf Goodman and Neiman Marcus), is strapped for cash, having skipped a $100 million payment to bondholders on Dec. 30 (Happy New Year to you!).

headline: Robust December Sales And Membership Strength Could Be A Game Changer For Costco Wholesale (COST)
summary: In early January 2026, Costco Wholesale reported that December net sales rose to US$29.86 billion, up 8.5% year over year, bringing year‑to‑date net sales to US$101.83 billion, an 8.3% increase versus the prior period. This solid sales performance, alongside consistently high membership renewal rates around 90% and growing Executive memberships, reinforced confidence in Costco’s warehouse‑club model and membership‑driven revenue base. We’ll now examine how Costco’s strong December sales...

headline: Trump tariffs live updates: Trump's duties face potential verdict as US Supreme Court sets Friday for rulings

headline: A US Trader’s Guide to the Supreme Court’s Looming Tariff Ruling
summary: The equity market has extended its rise into the new year, with the S&P 500 Index hovering near a record.  Treasury yields have also come down from their mid-2025 peaks as traders bet the Federal Reserve will keep cutting rates while the economy cools.  If the nation’s top court says Trump exceeded his power with the blanket tariffs on countries around the globe, there will still be significant longer-term uncertainty, given that the White House could seek to re-impose similar levies by invoking different legal authority.

content.title: A US Trader’s Guide to the Supreme Court’s Looming Tariff Ruling
content.summary: The equity market has extended its rise into the new year, with the S&P 500 Index hovering near a record.  Treasury yields have also come down from their mid-2025 peaks as traders bet the Federal Reserve will keep cutting rates while the economy cools.  If the nation’s top court says Trump exceeded his power with the blanket tariffs on countries around the globe, there will still be significant longer-term uncertainty, given that the White House could seek to re-impose similar levies by invoking different legal authority.

headline: Here's how much more complex Trump 2.0 tariffs are — and how much the Supreme Court could roll things back

headline: Betting Markets Say Supreme Court Will Scrap Trump Tariffs. How to Play It.
summary: The Supreme Court may or may not issue a Friday ruling regarding the legality of President Donald Trump’s use of emergency powers to impose tariffs without the approval of Congress.  Kalshi and Polymarket, the top two prediction markets, are indicating that traders expect the Supreme Court will rule against Trump.  The odds of the Supreme Court ruling in favor of the tariffs are 27% at Kalshi while Polymarket is pricing in only a 25% chance.

content.title: Betting Markets Say Supreme Court Will Scrap Trump Tariffs. How to Play It.
content.summary: The Supreme Court may or may not issue a Friday ruling regarding the legality of President Donald Trump’s use of emergency powers to impose tariffs without the approval of Congress.  Kalshi and Polymarket, the top two prediction markets, are indicating that traders expect the Supreme Court will rule against Trump.  The odds of the Supreme Court ruling in favor of the tariffs are 27% at Kalshi while Polymarket is pricing in only a 25% chance.

headline: Factbox-Countries and industries most exposed to Trump's IEEPA-based tariffs
summary: Supreme Court is set to issue rulings on Friday on cases related to the legality of ​tariffs imposed by President Donald Trump under the International Emergency ‌Economic Powers Act. The administration faces the possibility of having to refund nearly $150 billion paid in ‌tariffs to importers if the court declares that the sweeping duties Trump has imposed under the IEEPA are illegal.

content.title: Factbox-Countries and industries most exposed to Trump's IEEPA-based tariffs
content.summary: Supreme Court is set to issue rulings on Friday on cases related to the legality of ​tariffs imposed by President Donald Trump under the International Emergency ‌Economic Powers Act. The administration faces the possibility of having to refund nearly $150 billion paid in ‌tariffs to importers if the court declares that the sweeping duties Trump has imposed under the IEEPA are illegal.
